Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (landlord and tenant statutes governing tenancies and related rights and remedies);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111.proposition: - Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111 and applicable public health statutes regulating habitability and sanitary housing conditions;

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: - 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq. (Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation) and related public health codes and local housing codes applicable in Worcester regarding infestations and vermin;

Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: - Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing that substantial defects that render premises unfit for their intended use may constitute a breach of the tenant’s rights);

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: - Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (1974) (discussing landlord obligations and tenant remedies for substandard conditions);
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is centrally about recognizing an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and explaining the landlord’s obligations and tenant remedies when premises are substandard. It details the landlord’s duty to maintain habitable conditions, clarifies that Civil Code repair-and-deduct is not the exclusive remedy, and holds that tenants may assert breach of the implied warranty as a defense in unlawful detainer, including rent reduction and damages. That squarely matches a citation for landlord obligations and tenant remedies for substandard conditions.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “We have concluded that a warranty of habitability is implied by law in residential leases in this state and that the breach of such a warranty may be raised as a defense in an unlawful detainer action. Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease… In most cases substantial compliance with those applicable building and housing code standards which materially affect health and safety will suffice to meet the landlord’s obligations….”

Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..raw_text: Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979)
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..proposition: - Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979) (discussing habitability and landlord obligations);
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the implied warranty of habitability and the scope of a landlord’s obligations in residential leases, including that a residential lease is effectively a sale of shelter and services and that the landlord has a nondelegable duty to maintain habitable conditions. It interprets New York Real Property Law § 235-b and explains what habitability requires and when a breach occurs. Thus, citing this case for a general discussion of habitability and landlord obligations is accurate and supported by the holding and reasoning.
Park W. Mgmt. Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y..relevant_excerpt: “A residential lease is now effectively deemed a sale of shelter and services by the landlord who impliedly warrants: first, that the premises are fit for human habitation; second, that the condition of the premises is in accord with the uses reasonably intended by the parties; and, third, that the tenants are not subjected to any conditions endangering or detrimental to their life, health or safety… Inasmuch as the landlord is vested with the ultimate control and responsibility for the building, it is he who has a corresponding nondelegable and nonwaivable duty to maintain it.”

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: - Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (warranty of habitability and related landlord obligations);
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely adopts and defines an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and describes the resulting landlord obligations (to deliver and maintain premises that are safe, clean, and fit for human habitation, covering essential facilities, non‑waivable, with notice and repair duties, and associated tenant remedies). The discussion and holding match the proposition that the case is authority on the warranty of habitability and related landlord obligations.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. This warranty of habitability is implied in tenancies for a specific period or at will… Additionally, the implied warranty of habitability covers all latent and patent defects in the essential facilities of the residential unit… Nor can this implied warranty of habitability be waived….”
